lead_paragraph: New research on potential allergens fits with a wider hypothesis that complete avoidance of risky substances doesn’t work well.

byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine who blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist and makes videos at Healthcare Triage. Follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.

headline.print_headline: Avoiding Peanuts to Avoid an Allergy Is a Bad Strategy
headline.main: Avoiding Peanuts to Avoid an Allergy Is a Bad Strategy for Most

snippet: New research on potential allergens fits with a wider hypothesis that complete avoidance of risky substances doesn’t work well.
abstract: The Upshot; growing body of evidence suggests that once-recommended practice of avoiding certain solid foods, including peanuts, when woman is pregnant or breastfeeding out of fear that child will become allergic to them later on is ineffective and counterproductive; many parents persist in following older guidelines, although latest research consistently shows avoidance is wrong approach.
